div1.p: Louise Kean writes about the success of Reed's yellow fever experiments with infected mosquitoes and clothing.

div1.head: Letter from Louise Young Kean to Mrs. Mason Young, December 14, 1900
div1.p:
One of our boxes
arrived on the transport
and the other we
are bothering the ex-
press people about. I
wish Helen had thought
to send me the receipt,
but I guess it will
turn up all right, after
a while. The books are
lovely, and I was very
glad to get my pic-
ture frames, they help
out the “garnishing” of
my parlor very much.
Please ask Helen what
she did about Mrs.
Stark's hat, she did
not mention it in
her letter.

Yesterday I drove in to
see Gertrude. Miss Shaw
and Murray were out
but I had a nice visit
with Gertrude. She was
very affectionate and
all dangerous subjects
were carefully avoided.
She seemed to be cheer-
ful, tho' I heard from
people who came down on the trans-
port, that she was very nervous
and very much depressed. As Madam
Misery is going to Morristown after
Xmas I infer that Bessie has not
insisted on the annual visit.

Dr. Reed has now three cases of
fever from mosquitoe bites, while
the men who have been sleeping
on infected bedding for twelve days
are getting fat. The yellow fever
board says there is no doubt that
the cases are genuine, and there is
likewise no doubt that the men
were infected by “loaded” mosquitoes.
Isn't it wonderful, you can hardly
realize how much this discovery means
to Cuba and the South, not to
speak of the saving of clothes etc.
for, of course, disinfection is perfect
rot now the mosquitoe theory is
established. I wish you could hear
Dr. Reed on the subject, he is so en-
tertaining and so
funny. Always threaten-
ing to go off on a
toot, but always with
a good reason as to
why the toot should
be put off until next
week.

Mama seems to be
improving, tho' she is
still very weak and
suffers some from the
siatica. She had a
very nice trip down, and
she was so pleased
at the way father
and Mase and Caz waited
on her in New York. I
gave her your messages,
and she said she was
very sorry not to see
you, but it was such
a bad day she was
glad you did not make
the trip to the city. Mama
is just as much pleased
with Cuba as you were,
but she is not strong
enough to take very
long drives yet.

I have been so busy
since I moved up here
that Martha's lessons
fell into innocuous
desuitude, but Mama has revived
them and she and Martha have
quite a seance every morning. Of
course she is Bobbie's devoted slave,
just as the rest of us are.

I am awfully glad Peg had such
a five time in Philadelphia. I
enjoyed her letter Helen sent me
very much.

Rannie and I bought a very pretty
old silver dish for the McCarrolls to-
day. It is round, six inches across
and weighs eleven ounces, so it is
handsome and heavy. I hope they
will like it, and will have sense
enough to see it is old and hand
made. I did not have it marked for
they do such things so badly here.
